PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: S. L. SMITH
Address: Watson, Sask.
Birthplace: New Alexandria, Ohio

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1905
Where did you set up housekeeping? On the homestead
Where had you been living before that? Ohio, U.S.A.
For how many people did you prepare meals? 3
How far was it to your nearest store? 9 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Prunes, Navy beans, flour, sugar, coffee

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Purity
In what quantities did you buy it? 48 lbs.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $3.00
How much did you use graham flour? None
Whole wheat flour? None
Was flour milled locally? No
What other grain products did you use? Creamy wheat
Cornmeal? No
Whole Wheat? No
Farina? No
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it?

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Purdy

In what quantities did you buy it? 48 lbs.

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $3.00

How much did you use graham flour? None

Was flour milled locally? No

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $0.60

What other grain products did you use? Creamy Wheat

Other? Whole Wheat

How did you grind it?
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 10 lbs.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Bell House.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 5 lbs.

At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? None.

Butter? None. Eggs? None.

What was the price of butter? None. Of eggs?

Did you pack eggs for winter? None. How?

Did you make butter? Yes. Some cheese? No.

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Mostly rabbits, Povesh, chickens, ducks, deer.

How did you get fresh meat? Seldom.

How often did you get fresh meat? Seldom.

How did you preserve meat? None.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.

If so what year was it organized? 1920.

Did you use game? Deer. What kinds?

For how long? About 2-3 seasons.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Caught some fish.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh.

Kinds? Povesh.
